article.paragraph: Political corruption sidebarPolitical scandals in the United Kingdomare commonly referred to by the press and commentators as "'sleaze".
article.heading: Sleaze
article.paragraph: A number ofpolitical scandalsin the 1980s and 1990s created the impression of what was described in theBritish pressas "sleaze": a perception that the thenBritish Conservative PartyConservativegovernment was associated withpolitical corruptionandhypocrisy. This was revived in the late 1990s due to accounts of so-called "sleaze" by the Labour government.

Councillors' expenses?Although prior to the catastrophic collapse of the towers, the phrase "a good day to bury bad news" (not actually used by Moore) has since been used to refer to other instances of attempting to hide one item of news behind a more publicised issue.

In 2002,Edwina Currierevealed that she had had an affair, beginning in 1984, withJohn Majorbefore he becamePrime Minister of the United Kingdom. This was criticised more harshly than may otherwise have been the case as Major had frequently pushed hisBack To Basicsagenda (see above), which was taken by the media as a form ofmoral absolutism.

In March 2006 it emerged that the Labour party had borrowed millions of pounds in 2005 to help fund theirUnited Kingdom general election, 2005general electioncampaign. While not illegal, on 15 March the Treasurer of the party,Jack Dromeystated publicly that he had neither knowledge of or involvement in theseloansand had only become aware when he read about it in the newspapers. A story was running at the time that DrChai Pateland others had been recommended forLife peeragesafter lending the Labour party money. He called on theElectoral Commission (United Kingdom)Electoral Commissionto investigate the issue of political parties taking out loans from non-commercial sources."Labour loans to be investigated",BBC, 15 March 2006SeeCash for Peerages.

Cash for Honours(2006). Following revelations about DrChai Pateland others who were recommended for peerages after lending the Labour party money, the Treasurer of the party,Jack Dromeysaid he had not been involved and did not know the party had secretly borrowed millions of pounds in 2005. He called on theElectoral Commission (United Kingdom)Electoral Commissionto investigate the issue of political parties taking out loans from non-commercial sources.

In November 2007, it emerged that more than 400,000 had been accepted by the Labour Party from one person through a series of third parties, causing the Electoral Commission to seek an explanation.http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/uk_politics/7111838.stm "Concern over secret Labour donor"],BBC, 25 November 2007Peter Wattresigned as the General Secretary of the party the day after the story broke and was quoted as saying that he knew about the arrangement but had not appreciated that he had failed to comply with the reporting requirements.http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/uk_politics/7113255.stm "Labour boss quits over donations",BBC, 26 November 2007

article.heading: 2010s

list.listitem: TheIris Robinson scandalin whichFirst Minister of Northern IrelandPeter Robinson (Northern Ireland politician)Peter Robinsonstepped aside for six weeks in January 2010 following revelations of his wifes involvement in an extramarital affair, her attempted suicide and allegations that he had failed to properly declare details of loans she had procured for her lover to develop a business venture.

The2010 Cash for Influence Scandal, in which undercover reporters for theDispatches (TV series)Dispatchestelevision series posed as politicalLobbyinglobbyistsoffering to pay Members of Parliament to influence policy.

On 29 May 2010Chief Secretary to the TreasuryDavid Lawsresigned from theBritish CabinetCabinetand was referred to theParliamentary Commissioner for Standardsafter theDaily Telegraphnewspaper published details of Laws claiming around 40,000 in expenses on a second home owned by a secret partner between 2004 and 2009 whilst House of Commons rules have prevented MPs from claiming second home expenses on properties owned by a partner since 2006. By resigning Laws became the shortest serving Minister in modern British political history with less than 18 days service as a Cabinet Minister.

The2013 Labour Party Falkirk candidate selection, which began following the announcement that the incumbent MPEric Joycewas to step down at theNext United Kingdom general election2015 General Election, erupted into a scandal after allegations were made on the significant infiltration of the selection process by theUnite the Uniontrade union Unite, currently the Labour Party's largest financial backer.

In April 2014Maria Miller, theSecretary of State for Culture, Media and SportCulture Secretary, resigned following pressure relating to the results of an investigation into her past expenses claims."Maria Miller row: Cameron faces questions, Labour says", BBC News, 5 April 2014. Retrieved 6 April 2014.

In September 2015,Lord Ashcroftpublished a biography ofDavid Cameron, which suggested that the Prime Minister took drugs regularly and performed an "outrageous initiation ceremony" which involved inserting "a private part of his anatomy into the mouth of a dead pig during his time in university. This became known aspiggate."A pig, some drugs and a disappointed billionaire: the life of David Cameron", Telegraph, 21 September 2015. Retrieved 21 September 2015.It also led to questions about the Prime Minister's honesty with party donor's known tax statuses as Lord Ashcroft suggested he had openly discussed his non-dom status with him in 2009, earlier than previously thought.
